ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Right Profound Sensorineural Hearing Loss (Single-Sided Deafness)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient presents with stable profound hearing loss on the right side following a head injury, with normal hearing on the left. Audiometry confirms profound SNHL on the right and normal sensitivity on the left.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To inspect the ear canals and tympanic membranes for any abnormalities.
To evaluate the integrity of the reflex arc and check for retrocochlear pathology.
To determine the degree, type, and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech recognition thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To verify the CROS fitting by matching the output to the open ear response of the better ear.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Diagnostic testing revealed normal hearing in the left ear and a profound sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear, consistent with single-sided deafness post-trauma. Middle ear function was normal bilaterally. Due to the severity of the right-sided loss and normal left hearing, the patient was identified as a candidate for a CROS system. Fitting was verified using Real Ear Measures to ensure acoustic transparency on the better ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal tympanic membrane performance bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent with Right ear stimulation; Present/Normal with Left ear stimulation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear: Normal hearing (0-10 dB HL). Right ear: Profound SNHL (95-110 dB HL at 250-2000 Hz; No Response at 4000-8000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear: SRT 15 dB HL, WRS 100% at 55 dB HL. Right ear: Could Not Test due to severity of loss.

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: Real Ear Measures (REM) for CROS fitting. Initial fit exceeded REUR by ~10 dB at 1500-6000 Hz (sounded tinny); adjusted to match REUR target.

proposed_items: Fit conventional wireless CROS system (BTE transmitter on right, receiver on left).
Use open-fit coupling (slim tube with open dome) on the better (left) ear to avoid occlusion.
Verify fitting using Real Ear Measures (REM) to match the Real Ear Unaided Response (REUR) of the better ear (acoustic transparency).
counseling_actions: Explain that CROS improves awareness of sounds from the 'bad' side but does not restore localization ability.
Advise that CROS does not restore binaural processing (squelch effect), so difficulty in noise may persist.
Counsel on using visual cues and strategic positioning in noisy environments.
Discuss reducing gain or deactivating the transmitter in specific noise situations where noise originates on the poorer ear side.

escalation.rationale_short: Patient is already under medical care (referred by physician); audiological management of single-sided deafness is the primary goal.

follow_up_plan.objective: Evaluate benefit of CROS system, assess performance in various listening environments, and validate fitting.

expected_outcome: Patient reported benefit from CROS due to increased ability to hear sounds occurring all around her.
Listening in the car became less frustrating due to improved ability to hear passengers on the right.
Localization of sound continued to present difficulties; patient relied on visual scanning.
Occasional difficulty reported in noisy environments, particularly if non-desired signals were on the poorer ear side.
Patient found sufficient overall benefit to continue using the CROS system.
